AM is conserved about any point. Let's take the point as the center of mass, COM of the bullet+block (which is close to the center of block if the bullet is light enough). 
After collision, the AM is only due to rotation about the COM. (I*omega). 
Before collision block has no AM (it's at rest). But bullet has AM about our point. It is equal to moment of its linear momentum ( r x mv).
Both are equal.

Energy is not conserved in this collision. And different E is lost in the two cases.

Angular momentum IS conserved in this collision. 

Lets consider a point P, where the bullet was fired from. 
Before collision AM was zero about P.
After collision, the block+bullet system's total AM about P has two components. 

1) due to rotation of system about its center of mass ( I*omega). This one is intuitive and easy to see. 

2) due to the moment of the linear momentum of system's center of mass about P ( r x Mv ).    

Both these add up to zero (they are in opposite directions).

Several years ago (2002-2006ish), there was an internet phenomena called "l33t". l33t was a twisted way of saying "leet" which was short for "elite", and was commonly used by gamers (Counter-Strike guys...a predominant user base), that spread and proliferated. What l33t was, was a method of writing a language and replacing as many letters with numerals or other symbols, while still making some sort of sense. l33t 5p34k !5 l!k3 7h!5 (leet speak is like this).
